title: Schoolgirl, 12, who used deodorant 'like it was going out of fashion' died after being overcome by aerosol fumes

A 12-year-old schoolgirl died after she was overcome by deodorant fumes at the start of the summer holidays, an inquest has heard. 
Paige Daughtry had been so keen to protect her personal hygiene she used under-arm body spray as if ''it was going out of fashion.'' 
Her devastated mum told the hearing her daughter would spend "hours" spraying the substance because she "didn't want to smell". 
"She used to spray it in small rooms and I used to tell her off," she added. 
Paige was found lying face-down on a bed in a caravan her family were renting at a holiday park in Fleetwood, near Blackpool, Lancashire. 
She was rushed to hospital where she tragically died two hours later. Paige was found lying face-down on a bed in a caravan her family were renting (Photo: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd) The tragedy occurred at a holiday park in Fleetwood, near Blackpool, Lancashire (Photo: Mercury Press) 
Police investigating the tragedy on July 18 last year found Paige's can of Right Guard deodorant lying on grass outside the caravan's en-suite bathroom. 
It was discovered close to where the schoolgirl was found. 
Doctors said the schoolgirl had inhaled butane and isobutane from the tin - but said there was no evidence of 'chronic use.' 
An inquest heard Paige was a ''bright and talented'' student from Greater Manchester who had harboured ambitions of a career in music or art. 
Baby boy found dead in his bed at seven months old by his heartbroken mother 
She was three days into her trip at the Cala Gran holiday park with her parents, Ann and Stuart, and older sister, Catherine. 
Speaking at the Heywood hearing, Mrs Daughtry, 36, said her daughter had been "overusing deodorant" before her death. 
''She would spend hours in the bedroom and would spray and spray as she didn't want to smell," she told the inquest. Police found Paige's can of Right Guard deodorant lying on grass outside the caravan's en-suite bathroom (Photo: Manchester evening news) She was three days into her trip at the Cala Gran holiday park (file picture) (Photo: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd) 
She added: ''I suppose that's something every 12 year old girl would do, spraying deodorant. But she was overusing deodorant. 
"It was more than we would have expected any girl to put on. 
"But there was never a point we started to think there was an issue - not in the way we would have thought she was doing any sniffing or anything like that. 
"There were no indications what so ever, I would have noticed. 
'I came to say sorry': Jeremy Hunt attends memorial service of toddler who died after NHS failed to spot sepsis 
''She was a strong character. 
"My feeling is she was the way she was and there was no changing her no matter what we did she marched to her own beat, that was Paige.'' 
Mrs Daughtry said her daughter - who attended Royton and Crompton School in Oldham - had been looking forward to the holiday. 
''Paige was looking forward to the holiday - we went every year," she said. Doctors said Paige had inhaled butane and isobutane from the tin - but said there was no evidence of 'chronic use' (Photo: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd) 
"We did some swimming and went into Blackpool and came back. 
"We were as a family together all day, she did have a bit of a strop that day - but that was her being a teenager. 
''Paige went into our bedroom and my husband went off to take some photographs on the beach. 
''From Paige going in her room and me shouting her it was about 10 or 15 minutes. That room was a bit cooler and the window was open. 
''I think that's why she decided to go in there and all the chargers were in there and she wanted to listen to music. 
"I shouted, there was no response, I went in and sought assistance. I was screaming at the top of my lungs, trying to pull her off her the bed and phone 999.'' 
Two holidaymakers from neighbouring caravans came to assist with CPR before paramedics arrived and took Paige to Blackpool Victoria Hospital. 
Forensic pathologist, Dr Jonathan Metcalfe said the cause of Paige's death was ''inhalation of volatile substances.'' (Photo: Mercury Press) 
He added: "Analysis of brain samples revealed two substances present in aerosols - they are known as volatile substances. They are known to be present in Right Guard deodorant which was present at the scene. 
"Their presence is consistent with inhalation. Death may result from the toxicological effects. The substances are butane and isobutane. 
''There was no natural disease that has contributed to her death. There was no evidence of heavy use and no direct evidence that there was chronic use." 
Det Chief Insp Jason Richardson from Lancashire Police said: "A can of Right Guard deodorant was found located on grass outside the caravan, outside the open window of the en suite toilet attached to the bedroom Paige had been found - as if dropped out of the window. 
''It was found to be empty and was seized as evidence. Ann reported that she noticed Paige using a lot of deodorant.'' 
A coroner's officer said: ''It was established Paige had previously used deodorant - a direct quote from Mrs Daughtry herself being 'like they were going out of fashion'. An empty canister was found outside the caravan window." The coroner recorded a conclusion of death by misadventure (Photo: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd) 
Recording a conclusion of death by misadventure coroner Alan Wilson said: "This is the unintentional consequences of a deliberate act. Paige was inhaling the fumes from the deodorant but what she didn't intent is the consequences. 
''It's most likely that inhaling those fumes has most probably led to her heart rhythm being affected and led to her death. 
"It may have been in recent times she got into the habit of inhaling some fumes. I do find she was probably inhaling deodorant fumes for what ever reason during that day. Mr and Mrs Daughtry can I pass on the condolences of everyone here. '' Read More Shocked sunbathers scream and scatter as wild boar charges across beach at packed holiday resort 
Paige's grandfather John previously paid tributes to his granddaughter on Facebook. 
In a post shortly after her death, he wrote: "On Monday night my wife and I got the worst phone call a grandparent could ever receive. 
"Our daughter Ann Daughtry rang to tell us that our beautiful, vibrating, ever happy go lucky and always singing granddaughter had passed away. 
"We can't describe how we felt - our hearts have been broken there is nothing more I can say,except a part of us has been ripped away from us. A spokesman for Cala Gran Holiday Park said at the time: "This is a tragic incident, and our heartfelt condolences go to the girl's family" (file picture) (Photo: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd) 
"Paige our sweet baby girl we will never forget you, as long as we live and every day we think of you you will be alive in our hearts night and god bless sweet. 
"You will be up there teaching everyone to sing so 'til we meet again, sleep tight." 
The 12-year-old's auntie posted: "Paige u was my mini mayhem. 
"We laughed and I have so many happy funny memories. 
"I saw u come into this world and held u so tightly wen u was born. 
"I promised u I would be there for u and ur sister and love you with all my heart. 
"Ur mum and dad and big sis have lost there star and u have become the brightest star in heaven. 
"Paige I love you always and cause mayhem up there." Read More 
A spokesperson for Lancashire Police said at the time: "The girl was taken to Blackpool Victoria Hospital for treatment but sadly died a short time later. 
"The death is currently being treated as unexplained." 
A spokesman for Cala Gran Holiday Park said: "Emergency services were called to the park on Monday evening to tend to a 12-year-old female guest who later passed away. 
"This is a tragic incident, and our heartfelt condolences go to the girl's family, who we have offered our support to."
